importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The current year, 2025, is highlighted as a period of intensifying extreme weather events globally, including floods and wildfires, emphasizing the immediacy of the need for global early warning systems.

keyTakeAways: Nearly half of all countries lack early-warning systems for extreme weather events, leaving millions—especially in developing nations—vulnerable.
The WMO reports that disaster-related deaths are six times higher in countries without early-warning systems, with 90% of such deaths occurring in developing countries.

Over the last decade, the number of countries using multi-hazard early warning systems has increased from 52 to at least 108, but still, half of 62 assessed countries have only basic or less than basic capacity.
The situation is particularly dire in fragile, conflict-affected, and violence-prone regions.
Progress is being made in Africa, with more countries establishing functional websites and issuing standardized alerts.
Extreme weather events in 2025 have included massive flooding in Pakistan, Nigeria, and South Korea, and wildfires in southern Europe and the US.
The collapse of a Swiss glacier in May 2025 served as a real-world example of how early monitoring and warnings can save lives, leading to the evacuation of the village of Blatten.
Permafrost melt is expected to increase glacier collapses and rockfalls, highlighting the long-term necessity of robust early warning systems.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The World Meteorological Organization (WMO), part of the United Nations, has released a report urging global action to close critical gaps in early-warning systems for extreme weather. Despite progress in some regions, nearly half of all countries lack adequate systems, with disaster-related deaths six times higher in nations without them—most of which occur in developing countries. The article highlights real-world cases, including floods in Pakistan, Nigeria, and South Korea, and wildfires in southern Europe and the US, as well as a successful evacuation of the Swiss village of Blatten due to a predicted glacier collapse in May 2025. Experts stress that early warnings not only save lives but also protect vital infrastructure and economic assets, especially as climate change intensifies weather extremes and permafrost melt threatens further instability.
title: UN pushes for worldwide disaster alerts as extreme weather ‘spirals’
